currentDoc:
Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the parenguardians

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.  This is not so

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine. How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do bel

This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be somesor

I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will ad

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine. How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  These programs should b

This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, th

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independ

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting fundi

I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.

This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required

If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these

If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may b

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine. Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the scho

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  T

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  This can

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students. I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students. Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products. Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leavea a

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students su

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised a

Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product. Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position.

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position.   I think products like

This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position.   I think products like toilet paper are differ

This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position. Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide certnecessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position.   I think products like toilet paper are different because they are often cheaper to buy.

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide certain necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position.

Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide certain necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position.

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide certain necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position. 

Ultimately, schools number one focus should be education.  If

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide certain necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.

Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide certain necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position. 

Ultimately, schools number one focus should be education.  If these schools have to divert their time to oth

I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position. 

Ultimately, schools number one focus should be education.  If these schools have to divert their time to other non-education area

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position.

Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide certain necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position. 

Ultimately, schools number one focus should be education.  If these schools have to divert their time to other non-education areas, I believe this will harm the school's abili

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide certain necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position. 

Ultimately, schools number one focus should be education.  If these schools have to divert their time to other non-education areas, I believe this will harm the school's ability to educate.  Schools

This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide certain necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position. 

Ultimately, schools number one focus should be education.  If these schools have to divert their time to other non-education areas, I believe this will harm the school's ability to educate.  Schools should pass off the

If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position. 

Ultimately, schools number one focus should be education.  If these schools have to divert their time to other non-education areas, I believe this will harm the school's ability to educate.  Schools should pass off the responsiblity of pro

Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide certain necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position. 

Ultimately, schools number one focus should be education.  If these schools have to divert their time to other non-education areas, I believe this will harm the school's ability to educate.  Schools should pass off the responsiblity of providing pads and tampons to other programs t

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, I do not believe that schools should provide free pads and tampons for students.  The school should not have to worry about feminine products for the students.  This should be the responsibility of the student's parental guardians.    The main focus of school should be learning.  Now, if the school wants to set the students up with caregiving programs that will provide these items to the students, then I think that is fine.    I do not believe that the school should be required to provide these items.   Products like these can eat into already low budget of many school systems.

Additionally, it is not the school's responsibility to provide certain necessities for the students.  If there is a student who is a Type 1 Diabetic, it is not the school's responsibility to provide that student with insulin.  The student's parents are responsible for providing that.  I do believe that there needs to be some sort of program that will address these needs if the parental guardians can't do it.  However, these programs should be independent from the school.  

I think that many school systems would have a hard time getting funding to buy feminine products.  That is more of a reason why schools should not be required to provide these products.    Students may become dependent on the school to provide the product.  If the school system is having a hard time getting the budget for these products, it can leave the students surprised and in a bad position. 

Ultimately, schools number one focus should be education.  If these schools have to divert their time to other non-education areas, I believe this will harm the school's ability to educate.  Schools should pass off the responsiblity of providing pads and tampons to other programs that are independent o
